question: 助動詞
userExplanationLong:
the morphemes suffixed to the six basic forms of verbs and adjectives in order to conjugate them into more complex forms.
  • after ren'youkei
    • ～ます, Polite form. 食べます, 飲みます
    • ～た, Past form. 食べた, 飲んだ, 可愛かった
    • ～て, Connective form. Conjunctive form. 食べて, 飲んで, 可愛くて
    • ～たい, Desiderative form. 食べたい , 飲みたい 
    • ～やがる, To have the nerve to 嘘をつきやがる
  • after ren'youkei of verbs, stem of adjectives
    • ～そうだ Seems like. 死にそうだ 
  • after shuushikei of verbs, stem of adjectives
    • ～らしい I heard that. It seems that. 
      • ここに来るらしい
      • 美味しいらしい
      • 綺麗らしい
  • after mizenkei.
    • ～ない. Negative form. 食べない, 飲まない
    • ～(さ)せる. Causative form. 食べさせる, 飲ませる
    • ～(ら)れる. Passive form. 食べられる,  飲まれる 
    • ～う. Volitional form. 食べよう, 飲もう
    • ～ぬ Negative form. Same meaning as ~nai ～ない, but its usage is different.
      • 飲まぬ I] won't drink [it].
    • ～ん A contraction of ~nu ～ぬ.
      • 知らん I] don't know.
      • 怪しからん Not appropriate. Scandalous. Outrageous.
  • after rentaikei.
    • ようだ  Works basically like a noun.
      To seem like.
      • 時間がかかるようだ
  • after nouns and the root of na-adjectives.
    • だ Copula. これだ, 綺麗だ
    • です
In English, jodoushi is often confusingly translated as "auxiliary verb." There are various types of auxiliary verbs in Japanese, and jodoushi are the ones that least look like verbs. I mean, nai is an adjective, and even the ~ta ～た of past forms is a jodoushi.
 
In dictionaries, it's abbreviated to jodou 助動.
